transcript_chunks.text: ghostwire tokyo was just okay while this first person jumped through tokyo oozes style and neon few things in the 10 and a half hours it took me to roll credits wowed me the combat is visually stunning but shallow the map is packed with activities but they're not all that interesting there's verticality to the world but it feels stiff bosses are grotesque but the battles themselves aren't engaging ghostwire tokyo is an open world game so there's definitely serotonin and satisfaction in clearing tory gates to remove the fog of war and finding one of the 25 hidden tanookies but you'll find all of this as rinse and repeat as you battle the same faceless enemies again and again and again is it bad no feeling the dual sense intensely rumble in your hands as you rip the core out of a vanquished foe is fun but ghost fire tokyo doesn't iterate on its ideas so the ninth hour of talking to a sparkly blue ghost with a simple fetch quest is a lot like the first i have a full review up now as a

foe is fun but ghost fire tokyo doesn't iterate on its ideas so the ninth hour of talking to a sparkly blue ghost with a simple fetch quest is a lot like the first i have a full review up now as a kind of funny gamescast but in short
